job_title: Faculty in La Verne, CA
pros: If you like consistency, a lack of change in practices, and working in silos, this is the place for you.
cons:
If you’ve ever wondered how oppressive systems continue in history, look no further. This is quite honestly one of the worst places I’ve ever worked. If you value yourself, your time, your worth, and mental health, hard pass on this institution. 

This place only works when you’ve got your head down and accepting their mediocre pay and taking hook line and sinker their optical facade of ‘equity’, but once you test those theories, you’ll find this place is anything but equitable. Test it out, if you are a minority, ask them about their retention rates (especially of minoritized groups), you’ll see who they are immediately. 

People here value their titles more than human-centered approaches. You will be tossed aside and thrown out if you try and exercise any inkling of empowerment because this place will rob you of it. 

Save for some of the folks who actually know how to do their jobs, the place is full of paper-pushers, who have mastered the art of ‘email forwarding’, and passing the buck on to the next person who also does not know how to do their job. If you want something taken care of by any department, be prepared for a long wait, with most just forgetting they are employed at this place, or others who think they’re too good or too important to respond to you. 

The treatment you’ll get from some departments is nothing short of inhumane that I don’t know how an institution like this has proceeded to operate for so long with their cruelties and yet pass themselves as a ‘student-centered’ institution. If that’s the case, why are their enrollments continually dropping and students are pursing legal action against this place? 

If you get a job offer or an interview with this University: RUN. You’ll be robbed of soul, life, dignity, and a chance at better pay compared to industry standards, it is a true bait and switch. For instructors, the pay is abysmal for terminally degreed workers. Pay is nearly half of related-industry standards, and for staff, at least 35%+ lower than most other industry professionals, which is not a living wage in the state of CA. However, this is not the case with their leaders, Director level and above are paid their market value.

Overall, it is adequate as a starter institution, but stay longer than 4+ years and you’ll stagnate fast, as their adherence to the archaism of outdated institutions dulls their sharpness and leaves them inept at competing against an ever-evolving educational marketplace.

job_title: . . . in La Verne, CA
pros: The University of La Verne has a wonderful mission that caters to so many different types of students.  It has been ranked one of the most diverse universities in the country. Comp time is something that is unheard of at ULV - if you're an administrative professional employee, you will work a lot of over time with no compensation.  Promotions are hard to come by and raises are small.  Employees are not as respected as senior managers think the employees.  Many employees (faculty, AP staff and classified staff) are unhappy and it's known, which has brought the morale down at ULV.

job_title: Administrative Professional in La Verne, CA
pros: So the real up-side to ULV is the tuition discount. It takes 3 years to kick in fully,  and for the employee you can only get a degree at ULV (so it has very limited value) but for kids it is in a program that pays tuition at a huge range of really good universities, That is why quite a large percentage of the staff stay.
cons:
There are so, so many problems:

Quality- overall the largest issue. The quality of the students (below CSU level, way below) and generally the faculty is not great either. Adjuncts range in quality hugely- as recruitment is based on who you are friends with. Most of the full time faculty couldn't get a job anywhere else, they like to pretend they are there as they really want to support first gen students, but that is BS, they are really just not up to the measure to work elsewhere. The professional staff tend to be better- but it is really hard to get fired so who knows. 

Cult of personality- so the entire place is small and run via personality driven decision making. There is no accountability (literally no process for a yearly review and faculty have no review after tenure) so it is really irrelevant how well you do your job. You are surrounded by people who are working as they have a friend of relative who got them the job, they are related to a manager, or they graduated from ULV. 

Staffing- so most complain about understaffing, and that is part of the problem, but it is more that there are not enough competent people to do the work. There are areas that are thinly staffed, but for the most part there are just people who need to be fired so someone who can do the job can be hired. It is not really capacity as much as capability. 

Pay- low, lower than other places, but if you aren't doing any work then maybe you are being overpaid? There has also historically been issues with people brought on at different salary levels, literally with no consistency so there are people who are grossly overpaid and others who are hugely underpaid. The biggest issue was people being paid as "receptionists" when they were really doing coordination work- to save about $7,000 a year. 

Lack of management- so there are two forms of management. Over-promoted internal staff- who actually care about ULV but probably don't know what they are doing or External recruits who are supposed to be bringing best practice (highly questionable if that is happening) and are there just long enough to get the promotion on the resume, get on the conference circuit and get another job. Neither is good, I am not sure which is worse. The later has been a real issue as of late due to attempts to get big projects for a media splash- rather than quality and consistent education. 

Internal policies- not followed if they exist at all. Jobs don't even float internally, you just find out about a promotion/new role for someone's favorite later. Really unprofessional and no training for these newly promoted managers.

job_title: Information Security Officer in La Verne, CA
pros:
-403b 10% university matching + 5% mandatory employee matching.
-generous sick leave (1 day/mo.) + PTO (22 days/year) + paid vacation between Christmas & New Years
-there are some nice folks here
-flexible hours for the most part
-it is rewarding to help students learn new concepts & to be given occasional opportunities to speak to students
cons:
-salary below industry standard
-many tenured faculty encountered were extremely rude, immature, and resistant to anything technological changes necessary to improve the information security posture of the university.
-even within the Office of Information Technology (OIT), there are several folks who've worked there a long time that are unwilling to listen to desperately needed security recommendations because they are so set in their processes which made for a toxic work environment.
-unwillingness of management to resolve disputes between lower-level employees when conflicts arose which affected ability to perform stated role.
-unwillingness by nearly all faculty to attend mandatory information security training despite the fact this group of employees needs it the most.
-faculty senate is a toxic plague that is infecting every aspect of the university as tenured faculty complain about every aspect of administration and demand that they be given special treatment and a say in every major policy or decision.  Most of the faculty do not like the staff, so there is a definite divide between the two groups of employees with the faculty thinking that they are better than everyone else and should be given special treatment when the fact is that many are completely out of touch with reality, are change-resistant, and care only about achieving tenure.
-no opportunity for advancement in the Information Security Officer role, this is a dead end role so if that's your thing and you want to be relegated to manually dissecting phishing email attacks then by all means... The role should be re-classified as a CISO, but the CIO doesn't want to hire someone that may potentially offer different recommendations to the executive council or board of trustees when having the ISO work directly for the CIO is an obvious conflict of interest.
-no budget is allocated for information security & as an ISO have zero budgetary control or influence
-there is a general reluctance among OIT fellow system administrators to give the security administrator (ISO) the necessary system admin permissions they need to perform the job because they feel like their jobs are being threatened.
-nepotism and cronyism abound here.
-it is unrealistic to expect one information security professional to be able to perform the wide range of information security tasks:
SIEM analysis, security awareness training, develop security policies, digital forensics, incident response, etc., etc.  (too much for any given person but the university can only afford to hire one person; hiring an intern or student worker is a very bureaucratic process so essentially it was not an option)
-though the university thought it was ready to hire an ISO, they were not mature enough to accept many of the best practice recommendations that were provided which is very telling of the work environment
